Award.AwardTitle: Tailoring the Properties of Heterostructures of Monolayers: Epitaxial Growth and Doping
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description:
Heterostructures of semiconductor materials, which provide enhanced electrical and optical characteristics well beyond that of each individual constituent material, have been the key enabling element in modern telecommunication, energy-efficient displays, and energy harvesting technologies. This project explores a new approach to synthesize heterostructures made of sheets of two-dimensional materials, in which atoms within a sheet form strong bonds but interactions between the layers are very weak. Atomic-resolution imaging and calculations are carried out to understand how this characteristic anisotropic bonding facilitates the growth and assembling of the single atomic layers similar to LEGO blocks, thus allowing the design and synthesis of new materials with tailored properties and functionalities beyond the limits of materials that currently exist in nature. This project provides graduate and undergraduate students interdisciplinary training in areas of materials synthesis and characterization at the atomic scale, as well as electronic structure calculations. The open source distribution of electronic structure codes continues to provide the scientific community the benefits of our team's code development efforts. An ongoing Research Experience for Teachers outreach program brings cutting-edge research on two-dimensional materials to high-school students to inspire their interest in science and engineering.

Technical Description:
This project aims to gain an atomic scale understanding of 1) the inherent grain boundary formation during the van der Waals (vdW) epitaxial growth of two-dimensional transition-metal dichalcogenides, and 2) the doping and bandgap engineering of their heterostructures. Leveraging the capability of integrating molecular beam epitaxy, scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and atomic force microscopy (AFM), the intrinsic materials properties such as band offsets across lateral junctions and work functions are determined by in-situ tunneling spectroscopy and force-bias spectroscopy, respectively. Layer thickness, doping, and band gaps are further accessed by ex-situ Raman spectroscopy and photoluminescence. The information obtained by these spatially averaged spectroscopic measurements is correlated with atomic scale structural information such as the alignment of vertical junctions, interface intermixing, local strain, and disorder obtained by in-situ atomic resolution STM/AFM imaging, as well as ex-situ transmission electron microscopy. Density functional theory calculations are tightly coupled to the experimental systems of interest, addressing issues related to structural properties (e.g., energetics of the modified vdW growth and the impact of defects and impurities) and electronic properties (interface states, band offsets, charging effects at grain boundaries, and work functions). This integrated approach enables the controlled growth, bandgap engineering, and characterization of heterostructures of monolayers at the atomic scale, all necessary steps towards tailoring their electronic and optical properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polymorphism describes the ability of materials to exist in more than one crystalline phases that are identical in chemical content. Two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenides are prime examples: in the 1H polymorph, the chalcogen atoms (e.g., S, Se) arrange in trigonal prismatic fashion around the metal atom (e.g., Nb, W), whereas in 1T the arrangement is octahedral (Fig. 1a). Other common variants such as the 1T? (distorted octahedral) and 1Td (orthorhombic) are distorted versions of these basic units (Fig. 1b).The chalcogen and transition atoms within the polymorphs are strongly bonded by covalent bonding, and thus stable at the single atomic layer limit, facilitating a new materials design paradigm by assembling layers of different polymorphs, either through epitaxial growth or mechanical assembly. Just like stacking Lego blocks, this new design methodology can lead to different polytypes where the stacking sequence determines the materials properties. For example, the 1T and 2H polytypes of molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) (Fig. 1c) are Mott insulator and semiconductor. This diverse spectrum of properties offers potential applications in fields ranging from electronic, optical, and quantum devices, to electrochemical catalysis.

During this project, we have discovered that polymorphs that do not exist naturally can be stabilized by the presence of epitaxial constraints, and their polymorphic junctions can also be synthesized with emergent properties. We have further discovered a common spiral growth mode for these materials. Details are described below.

1. Synthesis of single layer polymorphs that do not exist in natureWe show that the presence of epitaxial constraints can stabilize otherwise unstable polymorphs. For example, while the 1T polytype of NbSe2 does not exist in the bulk, at the single atomic limit, however, the 1T polymorph can be grown epitaxially on graphene by molecular beam epitaxy. Using scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), our investigation reveals a Star-of-David charge density wave pattern (Fig. 2), characteristic of a Mott insulator. Similarly, single layer 1T? WSe2 polymorph was also grown.

2. Synthesis of single layer polymorphic junctionsWe have also synthesized lateral and vertical polymorphic junctions of NbSe2 and WSe2.  For the 1H/1T? WSe2 lateral junction, edge states were found at the interface, indicating that 1T? WSe2 is a 2D topological insulator with 120 meV band gap. For the 1H/1T NbSe2 lateral junction, we have demonstrated the interfacial Coulomb engineering of the Mott insulator that leads to the collapse of the ?Mottness?, which is further confirmed in the vertical 1T/1H junction. For the 1T/1T vertical junction, we discovered two types of stacking orders with different electronic properties that are randomly distributed. This instability explains why the 1T phase does not exist in the bulk.

3. Spiral growth of multilayer MoS2 We have discovered that beyond the single layer limit, growth of these materials proceed via spiral growth mode, a direct consequence of their characteristic layered structure.  An example is shown in Fig. 3 for multilayer MoS2 grown by chemical vapor deposition. The spirals originate when the growth fronts are pinned at substrate steps, a unique mechanism that should be generally applicable to the growth of other layered materials on weakly interacting substrates.

This grant has provided research opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students in synthesis and atomic scale characterization of 2D materials, as well as computational modeling of their properties. This grant has also provided research opportunity for high school teachers to participate in the ?Make It Small: Exploring Nanotechnology Through 3d Printing? project by learning the growth and characterization of 2D materials. This grant has partially supported the maintenance of a state-of-the-art thin film synthesis and atomic scale imaging facility, which has also been used for classroom demonstrations for graduate courses and Research Experience for Teachers program.
